div.head: Preamble
div.p: This book was composed by the Most Reverend Don Friar Bartolome de las Casas, Bishop of Chiapa, in the year 1563.

In the kingdoms which by common name are called Peru in our world of the Indies, there have been found and are found daily in the most ancient tombs of the dead, which are called Guacas in their language, great and marvelous treasures of diverse precious things: namely vessels or flasks of various shapes made of purest gold and silver, precious stones, emblems or furnishings made of precious material fabricated in wondrous ways; also accumulations of gold and silver and riches of such quantity and quality that they seem not to exist in the nature of things but to be formed by the imagination of dreamers while sleeping. Now therefore it is asked whether these things will belong indifferently to anyone who, either by his own authority or by license of our kings of Spain or of governors ruling those regions in the royal name, has sought, dug up, found, and taken them with the intention of keeping them for himself, and thus whether he acquires ownership of those precious things or treasures and can retain them with a safe conscience.
